0a043dd54fb8cc3a949ba6d57d2beeceb4dd9e84.aiReadableSummary:
Title: Where to Find Free School Supplies in Los Angeles

Summary:
The start of the school year in Los Angeles County brings a surge in back-to-school spending, with an estimated $41.5 billion expected to be spent on K-12 students' school supplies this year, according to a survey by the National Retail Federation and Prosper Insights & Analytics. However, not all families have the means to purchase all the necessary supplies. The article highlights the challenges faced by teachers who often spend their own money on supplies for their students. While the California Education Code states that students in public schools should not be required to pay for educational activities or supplies, budget constraints can make it difficult for schools to provide these materials. The article then provides various resources and organizations that offer free school supplies to families in need.

Key Points:
- Back-to-school spending for K-12 students in Los Angeles County is expected to reach $41.5 billion.
- Some families struggle to afford school supplies while having to prioritize essentials like food.
- Teachers often spend their own money to provide supplies for their students.
- The California Education Code prohibits requiring students to pay for supplies, but limited budgets can make it challenging to fulfill this requirement.
- Several local organizations, including nonprofits, mental health clinics, churches, city programs, and clubs, provide free school supplies to families in need.
- Communities often organize back-to-school events that distribute backpacks filled with supplies.
- Nonprofits like Wellnest and the Salvation Army offer free school supplies through their assistance programs.
- The Assistance League of Los Angeles supports homeless, foster, and impoverished children through various programs, including Operation School Bell, which provides essential items like clothing, school supplies, and toys.
- The Assistance League partners with the Los Angeles Unified School District and the Department of Children and Family Services to identify and support children in need.
- The L.A. County Office of Education has liaisons who help homeless students and their families identify their needs, including school supplies.

Takeaways:
- Back-to-school spending is increasing, but not all families can afford basic school supplies.
- Teachers often spend their own money to provide supplies for students.
- The California Education Code prohibits requiring students to pay for supplies, but budget constraints can limit schools' ability to fulfill this requirement.
- Families in need can find free school supplies through local organizations, back-to-school events, and nonprofit programs.
- Partnerships between organizations and schools assist in identifying and supporting students in need.

Keywords: back-to-school spending, school supplies, budget constraints, California Education Code, local organizations, nonprofits, back-to-school events, Assistance League, homeless students, L.A. County Office of Education.

68e81f296526cab76356ba488b5ff938c288dd09.aiReadableSummary:
Title: The Housing Recession Is Over, According to Top Real Estate Economist

Summary:
According to Lawrence Yun, the chief economist of the National Association of Realtors (NAR), the US housing recession has come to an end. NAR data released in June showed a 0.3% increase in pending home sales compared to the previous month. The presence of multiple offers indicates that housing demand is outpacing supply. Yun mentioned that homebuilders are increasing production and hiring workers to meet the demand. Despite the recent increase, the Pending Home Sales Index remains 15.6% lower than the previous year. The NAR predicts an increase in the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage to reach 6.4% this year, which has led to current homeowners with lower rates being reluctant to move and has sidelined many house hunters. Moody's researchers also noted that higher rates will continue to impact homebuyers for years to come. The NAR projects a slight increase in the unemployment rate, from 3.7% to 4.1% in the next year. If mortgage rates decline, Yun suggests that a rush of buyers may occur later in the year and into the next. However, tight housing inventory has hindered improvements in affordability, as home prices have climbed for four consecutive months, with all major metro markets reporting monthly price gains. The Federal Reserve recently announced a 25 basis-point rate hike, and it is expected to be the final adjustment of the year before easing begins in 2024.

Key Points:
- Lawrence Yun, the chief economist of the National Association of Realtors (NAR), declares the end of the US housing recession.
- NAR data shows a 0.3% increase in pending home sales in June compared to the previous month.
- The presence of multiple offers suggests higher housing demand and a lack of supply.
- Homebuilders are increasing production and hiring workers to meet the growing demand.
- Despite the recent increase, the Pending Home Sales Index remains significantly lower (-15.6%) than the previous year.
- The NAR predicts a rise in the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage to 6.4% this year, leading to reluctant homeowners and sidelined house hunters.
- Moody's researchers note that higher rates will continue to impact homebuyers.
- The unemployment rate is projected to increase from 3.7% to 4.1% in the next year.
- A decline in mortgage rates could lead to a rush of buyers later in the year.
- Tight housing inventory has prevented improvements in affordability, as home prices have climbed for four consecutive months.
- The Federal Reserve recently announced a 25 basis-point rate hike, expected to be the final adjustment of the year before easing begins in 2024.

Key Terms:
- Lawrence Yun
- National Association of Realtors (NAR)
- Pending home sales
- Housing recession
- Housing demand
- Lack of supply
- Homebuilders
- Production increase
- Mortgage rates
- Homeowners
- House hunters
- Moody's researchers
- Unemployment rate
- Affordability
- Home prices
- Federal Reserve
- Rate hike

Key Takeaways:
- The US housing recession has ended, according to NAR's chief economist.
- Despite a slight increase in pending home sales, it remains lower than the previous year.
- Lack of supply and high mortgage rates have impacted housing demand.
- Homebuilders are working to meet the increased demand.
- Rising mortgage rates will continue to affect homebuyers.
- Unemployment rates are expected to rise slightly.
- A decline in mortgage rates could stimulate the housing market.
- Tight housing inventory has hindered affordability.
- The Federal Reserve's recent rate hike is expected to be the last for the year.
